WRITING.TEXT:
True, but I think companies will want some evidence that you can draw people before they had something over.
Put together some informative\entertaining reviews of components you've already got is one idea. I doubt anyone is going to give or loan components just because OP has said he wants to review them.
A magazine has an expected readership, which will convince manufacturers to send them bits for review. Same with Toms Hardware. Without that expected audience, can't see anyone offering something for nothing.

You're going to have to persuade either online shops, or gpu manufacturers, to loan you cards. Thry, in turn, will want some proof of predicted viewing figures to make it commercially sound. Can you show 500,000 youtube views or site visitors? What about examples of previous benchmark studies you've done?
If you can't provide the above, on what basis should these companies provide you with loan cards for testing?
Ah, that's an interesting approach. I do have multiple inputs on both monitors, and on both gfx cards. Cool, thanks :-) Will perhaps try it out with my existing GTX460 before upgrading

Cheers, sounds interesting!
Not too fussed about swapping cables over I guess; not going to be switching between work\gaming that often.

I think [toffeeface](http://www.reddit.com/r/AskReddit/comments/1pvbyq/what_do_you_think_was_the_worst_book_adaption_to/cd6iohw) had it right above; would have been better if they did a mini series of the book - would have suited the episodic nature a lot better.
I have seen mentioned in this thread, though, that the film was done as a prequel to the book, and there might (only a rumour as far as I could tell) be a second film in the works, which would cover the book. No idea how correct\likely this is though!
The book was certainly rich though, you're right!
Still a close call with the law though, and good job you had a decent cop!

WRITING.TITLE: [Build Help] Quadro GTX in same machine
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm acquiring the bits for my new machine and have a question about running a Quadro K2000 I have alongside a GTX (looking at a GTX770).
I will be alternating between gaming and 3d modelling (Autodesk Maya).
I've already got a 4770K, along with the Quadro K2000D. Really, I just wanted to hear if anyone else is successfully running a Quadro series card alongside a GTX before I buy my mobo, case etc, and how they are finding it - any problems to be aware of, or process for setting the primary card when modelling\gaming etc.
Welcome any advice\thoughts on the matter! Thanks in advance
Ah, you know what I mean I think - hash then
Yep weed, well solid anyway. Not sure it's as prevalent in the US?
UK based, and I'm not sure what the deal would be over here. Are you talking about probable cause in the US? (Not conversant with US law, but I've heard it mentioned before)
My bad, by dope I mean resin\hash
Good point; also the amount of paperwork they would have had to fill in would probably take them off the streets for a few hours too - time better spent on patrol and being generally available.

To be fair, the chapter\short story approach of the book wouldn't have translated well to a typical big screen film. I read the book over the summer, and loved it. Saw the film, loved it too. Both excellent, and in different ways.
Damn straight! After he left, all I wanted was a beer. Appreciated his kindness though

House was broken into by some mental woman looking for retribution against my flat mate, who was sensibly not there. I called the police whilst she was busting the door down. Police turn up, mob handed (like 4 patrol cars), and rush in. Detain crazy woman and bundle her off. I'm somewhat a bag of nerves, and having to give a run down of what happened to a couple of police in the living room. As I'm explaining to them, I notice a lump of dope on the sofa next to me (I say lump, it was probably a couple of grams tops), and stealthily shifted over and sat on it to hide it. Finished off talking to the cops who thanked me for my time and made to go. First cop walks down the hall to leave, the second one turns to me as he's leaving, grins, and comments "Just a friendly tip, but next time you call the cops, you might want to clean up any incriminating evidence beforehand", and glances at the sofa. I nervously chuckled, thanked him and that was that.
Close escape.
This is the most important question; "best build" is entirely subjective. Without knowing what you want to do with it, it's impossible to say how suitable your build is.

I have a healthy respect for the power, and ability to turn me into chunky niblets, of bears and sharks. But the animal that scares me the most is undoubtably the [Tarantula Hawk](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tarantula_hawk); a spider hunting wasp that preys on, you guessed it, Tarantulas. It doesn't even sneak up on them either, it hunts them them down, and then fucks them up in [face to face combat](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vzJFzNr5YL4).
And that's not even the worst part. Once it's immobilised the Tarantula (which they frequently do), it drags it back to it's nest, injects it with an egg, and leaves its young to gestate and grow inside, eating the helpless arachnid from the inside out.
Motherfuckers are scary!

Excellent! I've messed around with a few basic methods for creating spiral galaxies in Maya, but never really got anything I was happy with - this looks really nice. Appreciate the breakdown too, will try something similar myself :-)

Surely you can build one yourself, with the help of /r/buildapc
If you've not built yourself a PC before, it's far easier than you might think - give it a go!

There are only around 8 parts to your average computer, and they make it almost impossible for you to connect them the wrong way around.
* Case * Power supply unit (PSU) * Motherboard * Processor (CPU) * Memory (RAM0 * Graphics card (if you don't have this built into the motherboard, which is fine for some builds) * Hard drive * Optical drive (cd\dvd)
All of these make up your average computer. Plug in your keyboard, mouse and monitor and there you are.
Of course there are extra steps such a installing your operating system once everything is connected, but connecting all the hardware together is satisfying, and easy, to do.
Everytime I watch that scene, this line makes me want to go and jump on a horse and hightail it straight into battle. Fucking. Epic!
Assuming you've got a monitor as it's not listed above; is it 1080 or higher? You'll want it to be to make most of your 780.
We have a local charity, GreenGeek, that takes all kinds of old IT equipment, refurbishes it and passes it along to people in need. Might be worth exploring if something similar exists near you?
Good point; Windows 7 Home Premium x64 can only address 16GB RAM, so pro or ultimate is needed for 32GB
Holy crap, that's one sweet build :D

First of all, if there is any danger from overheating, your motherboard will alert you via some loud beeps. TBH, there is unlikely to be any issue from having the cooler slightly askew like that.
Try booting up into the BIOS and looking for a hardware monitor option. This will give you a CPU temp read out; watch this for a few minutes. Does it seem stable? Keep on watching, leave it on for 30 mins or longer if poss, read a book and keep an eye on the temps.
This should give you an idea of whether there is likely to be an issue. I'm using a monstrous Thermaltake cooler with one of the mb (physical) connectors having falled off; it's held on with 3 of the 4 clips, and works fine, no cooling issues at all. So really, it is very unlikely that you'll be able to heat damage your CPU; you'll get plenty of warnings before that is likely to happen, giving you plenty of time to shut the system down.
Damn, I am seriously tempted by the 6-core 3930k. What was your previous system, and how do the render times compare?, if you don't me asking. Tasty rig btw!
Venereal has a certain ring to it I think

Current build:
* Q9650 * 4GB * GTX460 * Corsair 120GB SSD
Running Maya 2014 on here, and it's generally fine. Only becomes sluggish when shaded viewport enabled with a high poly count (100,000).
Currently looking at a new build with a i7 4770, 16GB and a Quadro, for improved performance though. I hate slow render times, and my current CPU is 5 years old, so about due an upgrade!

Nice! I'm just looking at putting together a 6-core build myself, for broadly similar purposes. This looks like a great starting point, cheers :-) Out of interest, how do you find the GTX780 for Maya viewport performance? That's the key point for me, whether to get a 770 or a Quadro range (K2000D probably).
Looks good, you should be pleased!
That chapter gave me the heebie-jeebies imagining it. No guns. Chain mail. Waist high water. Zombies. Yeah, fuck that!

I'm still playing games, and at decent framerates @ 1080p, on my 5 year old CPU (Q9650), and 4 years old gfx card (GTX460) No reason to expect a decent buy now will only last 2 years. Games developers worth their salt will ensure games run across multiple levels of build.

I only ever use the viewport-smooth to get a preview of the meshsmooth functionality, but the extra resolution from using this increases the poly count, and I've always liked the (relative) simplicity of subdivs.
I've always avoid nurbs till now, but maybe I should take a look. Also, that opendiv you mention sounds interesting. Esp. coming from Pixar! Will try and check this out, cheers :-)
Indeed; less is more when it comes to thermal paste!

WRITING.TITLE: Face normals misbehaving when converting polys to SubDs and vice versa
WRITING.TEXT:
Had this problems many times, in various versions of Maya. I rarely use SubDs to haven't looked into why it's occuring. However I'm determined to get to the bottom of this issue for once!
When converting between Poly and SubD objects and back again, face (and possible edge) normals start misbehaving. [Few images here](http://imgur.com/a/AaHED) illustrate the issue.
Now I can easily solve this by just selecting the object and then "Set faces to normal", but I'm sure there must be some option I've missed, or something in my workflow, to be causing this. So, has anyone experience of this issue, or have any ideas why it's occuring?
Thanks in advance!

Damn, that sounds pretty tasty. I'm a big fan of peanut butter and (preferably German, peppered) salami. Crispy bacon sounds like an upgrade I'm gonna have to try
Agree about the bread toasting too

I like the confused, stuttering, barman, with tourettes, in the Boondock Saints.

WRITING.TITLE: [Build Help] Turning old gaming rig into a NAS\RAID box
WRITING.TEXT:
So I'm looking to build myself a new gaming\work rig in the near future, and want to do something useful with my current build and turn it into a NAS. I have 3 x 2TB drives I can use.
Basic specs of my existing setup are
* ASUS P5Q-E motherboard * 4 GB (4x1GB) * Intel Q9650 CPU * GTX460 video card * OCZ modular 600W PSU * Gigantic thermaltake volcano (or similar) cooler\heatsink
Now for this NAS, I realise that low power is desirable, as well as low noise. So I figure I sell the CPU (with cooler) and video card, and go for a low power CPU instead, and this is where I could do with some tips. This box will mainly be used for household backup and media streaming, but am open for other uses as well. Would something like a E8400 cpu be enough\overkill\underpowered for my needs, and still running at a low enough power rating to need a smaller heatsink?
I've also got an old GTX260 and a GTS250, which I've never used (spares from a friend), but they look still quite beefy. MB has no onboard, so my options are to use one of these cards, or sell them and get a dirt cheap PCI graphics card instead.
Would welcome any thoughts on the above!
Requiem for a Dream. It's the type of movie that I'm glad I watched, mainly because it means I never have to watch it again.
Sounds like my ideal job; I find cad work, and machinery in general, fascinating
Google Sketchup?

My old boss is blind. On valentines day one year, he brought in his packed lunch and scoffed it all as usual come noon. After a phone call with his wife later in the day, he sheepishly told us that his wife had apparently cut all the sandwiches into heart shapes unbeknownst to him
A group of bankers is called a wunch.
"Serious fraud squad, how can I help you?"

Thanks! Whisky books are a good idea; I actually have a couple of old whisky compendium books somewhere that should have overviews of some of the whiskies will be trying, and maybe something on the distilleries too - like it!
I was planning on getting some oatcakes in; apparently they're quite good at neutralising the palate between tastings. Good point on the glasses though, not even though of that. I have got 9 litres of highland spring mineral water in just to keep with the general Scottish theme, so plenty to rinse glasses out as well as for drinking.
I've even got some pipettes for adding water a drop at a time to any drams should folks wish; picked up a few at the Whisky Exchange a few years ago and found them really useful.
Thanks for the tips!

Thanks all!

I've got two Glencairns, a HP nosing glass, and my personal Talisker glass. Also got a selection of cut crystal glasses; not ideal, but they'll be fine for this occasion.

Like the idea of printing some reviews of to review before the tasting! I'll have a look for some this eve :-)
Will def. try and get together some group feedback

Great, that tasting\nosing chart looks just the ticket, cheers :-) Lots of nice descriptive text there that we can use!
You're right, the lineup is very much with an Islay slant, which I'm afraid is my doing and is generally reflective of my collection. In fact, the snow phoenix is probably the only non-peated one I own, although the Leif Erikson doesn't have a lot from memory.
I'll resist buying any more bottles at this stage; this evening is to try and help clear some shelf space so I'll have to stick with the Islay focus for this one.
Here's my [current drinking shelf](http://i.imgur.com/LwZFTox.jpg), sans the Bruichladdic Waves and the Snow Phoenix; you can see there is a definite Islay bias!

So I've invited a 5 friends over this weekend for some whisky tasting. Some of them have a tipple occasionally, but nothing specific. I'm looking for any feedback on my plans for the evening, and the scotches I'm going to break out. Not worked out any order yet, except for having the stronger, Islay beasts at the end.
* Glenfiddich Snow Phoenix * Bruichladdich Organic 2003 * Highland Park Leif Erikson * Bruichaddlich Waves * Jura Prophecy * Ardbeg Uigedail * Laphroaig Cairdeas 2010 * Laphroaig QC (Possible)
I was thinking of doing some group-reviews as well possible. Get some simple review sheets printed up for folks to jot their thoughts down. I'd like to have a sheet of some key words that can prompt people to comment on flavours\smells\sensations etc, rather than feeling a bit lost. Does such a thing exist?
I'm going to show folks this video beforehand as a primer for whisky tasing too. [HP Tasting video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Boj33DVSILQ)
edit: The whiskies above I've chosen as they're mostly the ones I have open at the moment. I am thinking of breaking out one of the nicer bottles I've had hanging around, but there are mostly Islay, with a few HP specials thrown in (Earl Magnus Thor).
Anyway, wondering if anyone has any tips or thoughts they could share to help the evenings planning! Thanks in advance :-)

WRITING.TITLE: Hosting a whisky tasting evening - looking for feedback\thoughts!
